Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Improving Critical Pipelines in Harnessing the Power of Galaxy Surveys and in Broadening Participation of Underrepresented Minorities
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Berlind will carry out a program to help strengthen two critical "pipelines." The first pipeline starts with measurements of galaxy clustering in redshift surveys, such as the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS), and ends in a physical understanding of cosmology and galaxy formation. The pipeline involves obtaining unbiased estimates of statistical and systematic errors, refining theoretical models used to fit the data, performing the fitting, and interpreting the results. A key tool required for every step in the pipeline is cosmological N-body simulations and associated mock galaxy catalogs. Dr. Berlind will complete the LasDamas simulations project and use it to enable the joint modeling of galaxy two-point, three-point, and group statistics in the SDSS. This should yield the strongest constraints to date on the relationship between galaxy properties and their underlying dark matter halos. The LasDamas simulations will also be used to study the detailed properties of dark matter halos with unprecedented precision.

The second pipeline is the one that produces professional astronomers from underrepresented minority groups. This pipeline has "leaks" at the K-12, undergraduate, and graduate parts, resulting in a very poor production rate of minority PhDs. Dr. Berlind will put in place a series of programs designed to patch this leaky pipeline. These include (1) creating scholarships for K-12 students to attend summer camps at Dyer Observatory, (2) creating a scholarship to support undergraduate physics students at Fisk University, (3) running an undergraduate summer research internship, and (4) designing and teaching an intensive workshop on statistics and data analysis for Fisk-Vanderbilt Bridge Masters students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Large galaxy surveys, like the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS), are yielding very precise measurements of the spatial clustering of galaxies on small scales. These measurements can be modeled to help understand the physics of cosmology and galaxy formation. The main goal of this research program has been to strengthen this modeling procedure and make it sufficiently accurate so that we may confidently rule out physical models. One of the key outcomes of this work is that the only way to build an accurate model of galaxy clustering is to use a fully numerical approach that relies on cosmological N-body simulations. Simulations are needed both to build models, and to reliably estimate systematic and statistical errors in the data. For this purpose, we designed and carried out the Large Suite of Dark Matter Simulations (LasDamas) project. This involved running several hundred simulations and constructing artificial galaxy catalogs that simulate several SDSS galaxy samples. Using these catalogs, we were able to estimate robust measurement errors for several galaxy clustering measurements. In addition, we built an accurate and computationally efficient modeling framework that allowed us to place the most reliable constraints on the relationship between galaxies and dark matter to-date. We concluded that the clustering of low luminosity galaxies is consistent with simple models of the galaxy-dark matter connection, whereas the clustering of high luminosity galaxies is in tension with such models.

A second goal of this research program has been to study the detailed properties of dark matter halos using the LasDamas simulations. A key outcome of this work has been an in-depth study of the clustering of halos and its dependence on secondary halo properties other then mass - i.e., "secondary" or "assembly" bias. We found that halo properties correlate strongly with a halo's distance to its nearest massive neighbor and this effect can fully explain secondary bias. We also performed a couple studies that attempt to detect galaxy secondary bias using SDSS data. In the most significant of these, we detected a clear signal of large-scale galactic conformity - the correlation of galaxy properties across distance - which could be a clear sign of secondary bias.

A third goal of this program has been to strengthen the professional pipeline that produces professional astronomers from underrepresented minority groups. This grant addressed this pipeline at several stages. In the K-12 stage, the grant supported many K-12 students from underserved areas of Nashville to attend summer "Space Camps" at Dyer Observatory. In the undergraduate stage, the PI hired a minority summer research student each summer of the grant. These students all completed research projects and went on to enroll in PhD programs. In the graduate stage, the PI taught a statistics bootcamp each May for students in the Fisk-Vanderbilt Masters-to-PhD Bridge program. Finally, the work carried out on this program has contributed to the training and the theses of several undergraduate and graduate students.
